content.description: Wyatt can hold a bottle between his fingers and palm at age six months, yet he is unable to grasp a piece of cereal between his thumb and index finger until age nine months.
content.question: Which of the following descriptions best represents the developmental perspective regarding these milestones in physical development?

choices.label: The age at which each grasping technique develops is dependent on the frequency of practice and modeling.
The exact age at which each grasping technique develops varies from infant to infant, but the order in which these physical stages occur is the same.
Most infants learn the finger-to-palm grasp more quickly than the thumb-to-index-finger grasp because of early bottle feeding.
Grasping an object between the index finger and thumb requires a level of adrenaline in the prefrontal cortex not present at age six months.

content.answer: The exact age at which each grasping technique develops varies from infant to infant, but the order in which these physical stages occur is the same.
